column1: 90178,Make a div fill the remaining screen space,"I am currently working on a web application, where I want the content to fill the entire screen. I have a header `div` and a content `div`. At the moment I am using a table for the layout like so:

Which works how I like. The table remains at 100%, and the `tdcontent` element is always less than 100%. Is there a way to achieve the same effect without using the `table`?",<table><css><html>,How to Make a Div Fill Remaining Screen Space Without Using Tables,"I am developing a web application where I want a content `div` to occupy the remaining screen space below a header `div`. Currently, I am using a table-based layout with the following structure:

This setup keeps the table at 100% height, but the `tdcontent` element is always less than 100%. I would like to achieve the same layout effect without using tables. How can I make a `div` fill the remaining vertical space on the screen dynamically?","CSS, HTML, Layout, Flexbox, Height, Full Screen"

492994,Compare 2 dates with JavaScript,"can some one suggest a way to compare values of 2 dates greater then, less then and not in the passed using javascript. They values will be coming from text boxes

Thanks",<date><compare>,"How to Compare Two Dates in JavaScript for Greater Than, Less Than, and Not Equal Conditions","I am receiving two date values from text boxes in my web application and need to compare these dates using JavaScript. Specifically, I want to determine if one date is greater than, less than, or not equal to the other. Can someone suggest an efficient way to perform these comparisons? Any example code would be helpful.","JavaScript, Date, Comparison, User Input"
500504,"JavaScript ""For ...in"" with Arrays","I've been told not to use ""for...in"" with Arrays in JavaScript but never received a satisfactory reason as to why not.

The question is: Why is using ""for ...in"" with array iteration such a bad idea?",<javascript>,"Why Is Using ""for...in"" Not Recommended for Array Iteration in JavaScript?","I've heard that using the ""for...in"" loop with arrays in JavaScript is discouraged, but I haven't been given a clear explanation as to why. Could someone explain the reasons why ""for...in"" is considered a bad practice for iterating over arrays? Are there potential issues or pitfalls I should be aware of?","javascript, array, iteration, for-in, best practices"

1149703,Stacktrace to string in Java,Easiest way to convert the result of Throwable.getStackTrace() to a string that depicts the stacktrace?,<stack-trace><java><tostring>,How to Convert a Throwable's Stack Trace to a String in Java,I'm looking for the simplest and most effective way to convert the stack trace obtained from `Throwable.getStackTrace()` into a string that accurately represents the stack trace. What is the recommended approach to achieve this in Java?,"java, stack-trace, exception, string-conversion"

2709821,python 'self' explained,"What is the purpose of the 'self' word in python. I understand it refers to the specific object created from that class, but i cant see why it explicitly needs to be added to very function as a parameter. To illustrate, in ruby, i could do this:
Which i understand, quite easily, However in python i need to include self:
Can anyone talk me through this? its not something ive come across in my (admittedly limited) experience.

Any help would be appreciated.",<python><self><explain>,Clarification on the Use of 'self' in Python Class Methods,"I am trying to understand the purpose of the 'self' parameter in Python class methods. I know that 'self' refers to the specific instance of the class, but I am unclear why it needs to be explicitly included as a parameter in every method.
For comparison, in Ruby, I can define a class and its method like this:
This works without explicitly passing the object instance.
In Python, however, I need to include 'self' as the first parameter:

Can someone explain why 'self' must be explicitly declared in Python methods and how it differs from other languages like Ruby? I am new to Python and would appreciate a clear explanation.","python, self, class, object-oriented programming, method parameters"
3106452,java servlet instantiation and session variables,"Out of curiosity and naivety:

Suppose, I have a webserver which holds numerous servlets. For information passing among those servlets I am getting the servlet context and setting session variables. Now, if 2 or more users send request to this server then what happens to the session variables? Will they all be common for all the users or they will be different for each user. If they are different, then how was the server able to differentiate between different users?
If there are n users accessing a particular servlet, then this servlet gets instantiated only the first time the first user accessed it or it gets instantiated for all the users separately?
Thanks,",<servlets>,"Clarification on Servlet Instantiation and Session Variable Behavior in Java Web Applications
_","I am seeking clarification regarding the behavior of servlets and session management in Java web applications. Specifically:

1. When multiple users send requests to a web server hosting several servlets, and these servlets utilize the ServletContext and session variables for data sharing, how does the server handle session variables? Are they shared across all users or are they unique per user? If they are unique, how does the server differentiate between different users' sessions?
2. Regarding servlet instantiation: If multiple users access a particular servlet, is the servlet instantiated only once when the first user accesses it, or is a new instance created for each user?
Any detailed explanation on how servlet instantiation and session management work in this context would be appreciated.

3289601,nulls object in Python?,How do I refer to the null object in Python?,<python><null>,How to Represent and Use Null or None Values in Python,"I'm trying to understand how to work with null or missing values in Python. Specifically, what is the proper way to refer to a null object or null value in Python? Are there standard practices or built-in objects used for this purpose? Any examples would be helpful.","python, null, None, null values"
5844672,Delete an element from a dictionary,"Is there a way to delete an element from a dictionary in python?
I know i can just call `.pop` on the dictionary, but that returns the element that was removed. What im looking for is something returns the dictionary *minus* the element in question.

At present i have a helper function that accepts the dictionary in question as parameter, and then returns a dictionary with the element removed, i just wondered whether there was more elegant solution?",<python><dictionary><remove>,"_
How to Remove an Element from a Python Dictionary and Return the Modified Dictionary

I'm working with a Python dictionary and need to remove a specific element. While I know I can use the `.pop()` method to remove an element, it returns the value of the removed item, which isn't exactly what I need. Instead, I want a way to obtain a new dictionary that contains all the original elements except the one I want to remove, without modifying the original dictionary.

Currently, I have a helper function that takes the original dictionary as a parameter and returns a new dictionary with the specified element removed. I'm wondering if there's a more elegant or idiomatic way in Python to achieve this without explicitly copying and filtering the dictionary each time.
Any suggestions or best practices for this?
python, dictionary, remove, dictionary comprehension, best practices"
9483757,END in git bash,"I'm trying to learn git with the help of git immersion http://gitimmersion.com/
But there's one thing that frustrates me whenever I use git log.

I can't figure out what to do next when I encounter this (END) word. I can't type any commands and I end up closing the current bash and open another. How do I type in the next command that I want to use?",<git>,How to Exit the 'END' Prompt in Git Bash When Viewing Logs,"I'm learning Git using the Git Immersion tutorial (http://gitimmersion.com/). While viewing the commit logs with `git log`, I sometimes encounter a screen that ends with the word '(END)', as shown in the screenshot below:

When this happens, I don't know how to proceed. The prompt doesn't accept any commands, and I end up closing the Bash window and opening a new one. How can I exit this 'END' prompt and continue using Git commands normally? What key commands should I use to navigate or exit this view?","git, git-log, terminal, bash, pagination"
10123953,Sort Javascript Object Array By Date,"Say I have an array of a few objects:
var array = [{id: 1 date: Mar 12 2012 10:00:00 AM}{id: 2 date: Mar 8 2012 08:00:00 AM}]

How can I sort this array by the date element in order from the date closest to the current date and time down? Keep in mind that the array may have many objects, but for the sake of simplicity I used 2.
Would I use the sort function and a custom comparator?",<javascript><datetime>,"_
How to Sort an Array of JavaScript Objects by Date in Descending Order
I have an array of objects in JavaScript, each containing an `id` and a `date` property, like so:

I want to sort this array based on the `date` property, with the most recent date closest to the current date and time appearing first. The array may contain many objects, but for simplicity, I am using just two.
Should I use the `sort()` function with a custom comparator? If so, how should I implement it to correctly compare the date strings?
